roles.title: FedRAMP Program Management Office
roles.description: The FedRAMP PMO resides within GSA and supports agencies and cloud service providers through the FedRAMP authorization process and maintains a secure repository of FedRAMP authorizations to enable reuse of security packages

roles.title: FedRAMP Program Management Office
roles.description: Members of the JAB include the chief information officers (CIOs) from the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, and General Services Administration. The JAB serves as the primary governance and decision-making body for FedRAMP.

roles.title: Prepared By
roles.description: The organization that prepared this SSP. If developed in-house, this is the CSP itself.

roles.title: Prepared For
roles.description: The organization for which this SSP was prepared. Typically the CSP.

roles.title: System Security Plan Approval
roles.description: he individual or individuals accountable for the accuracy of this SSP.

roles.title: Cloud Service Provider (CSP) Name
roles.description: Cloud Service Provider used by the client

roles.title: Information System Owner
roles.description: The individual within the CSP who is ultimately accountable for everything related to this system.

roles.title: Authorizing Official
roles.description: The individual or individuals who must grant this system an authorization to operate.

roles.title: Authorizing Official's Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual representing the authorizing official.

roles.title: Information System Management Point of Contact (POC)
roles.description: The highest level manager who responsible for system operation on behalf of the System Owner.

roles.title: Information System Technical Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual or individuals leading the technical operation of the system.

roles.title: System Information System Security Officer (or Equivalent)
roles.description: The individual accountable for the security posture of the system on behalf of the system owner.

roles.title: Privacy Official's Point of Contact
roles.description: The individual responsible for the privacy threshold analysis and if necessary the privacy impact assessment.

roles.title: General Point of Contact (POC)
roles.description: A general point of contact for the system, designated by the system owner.

components.title: Azure System
components.description: Azure System is a Leveraged Auth System for package: Azure Commercial Cloud

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
In Microsoft Azure Commercial Cloud, authentication is primarily managed through Azure Active Directory (AAD), which provides several methods to ensure secure access to services.

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users authenticate by entering a username and password. Azure enforces strong password policies to enhance security.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: Azure supports MFA, requiring users to provide a second form of verification in addition to their password. This can include a text message, phone call, or authentication app notification, adding an extra layer of security.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: Azure enables SSO, allowing users to access multiple applications with one set of credentials. This is facilitated through AAD, which integrates with various third-party applications and services.

4. **Conditional Access Policies**: Azure allows administrators to set conditional access policies that determine how and when users can authenticate based on factors like user location, device compliance, and risk level.

These authentication methods are integrated within the Azure platform, ensuring that users can securely access their applications and services while maintaining compliance with security standards.

components.title: Fortify Resource Group
components.description: Central hub for managing security and compliance-related services within the CSO.

components.title: Fortify Authorization
components.description: Handles authorization processes, ensuring only authenticated and authorized users or services can access system resources.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
The Fortify Authorization service implements several authentication methods to ensure secure access to the ACME system. The primary methods used are:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Each user is required to have a unique user ID and password. Passwords must meet specific complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all users accessing privileged accounts and is enforced through Azure Active Directory (Azure AD). Users must provide a second form of verification, which can include security keys (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or other CISA-approved methods. This adds an additional layer of security beyond just the password.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure AD and can integrate with external identity providers using OpenID Connect (OIDC) or OAuth 2.0. This allows users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one.

4. **Session Management**: Users are automatically logged out after a period of inactivity (15 minutes), and they must re-authenticate to resume their session. Additionally, the system locks accounts after five consecutive invalid login attempts, requiring a

components.title: ACME Pro Resource Group
components.description: Manages core functionalities and applications within the ACME service.

components.title: Data Warehouse and BI Resource Group
components.description: Focused on data storage, processing, and reporting services.

components.title: Approved 3rd Party Services SAAS
components.description: List of approved third-party SaaS providers integrated into the CSO.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
The Approved 3rd Party Services SAAS implements several authentication methods to ensure secure access to its systems. The primary methods include:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users are required to create unique usernames and passwords for their accounts. Passwords must meet complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access, enhancing security by requiring users to provide an additional verification method beyond their password. This can include security keys (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or other forms of second-factor authentication. MFA is enforced through Azure AD and is integrated with the login process for both privileged and non-privileged accounts.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO capabilities, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one. This is facilitated through OIDC/OAuth 2.x protocols and can integrate with external identity providers.

4. **Session Management**: User sessions are monitored, and if there is inactivity for a specified period (e.g., 15 minutes), users are prompted to re-authenticate. Additionally, after five consecutive invalid login attempts,

components.title: Smarty (API)
components.description: Address validation.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
The Smarty API implements several authentication methods to ensure secure access to its address validation service. The primary methods used are:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users are required to create unique usernames and passwords for their accounts. Passwords must meet complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access, enhancing security by requiring users to provide a second form of verification, such as a security token or mobile authenticator app. This is enforced for both privileged and non-privileged accounts, particularly when accessing the ACME Pro Application and Azure resources.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one. This is particularly useful for government agencies that may require integration with existing identity providers.

4. **Session Management**: User sessions are monitored and require re-authentication after periods of inactivity (e.g., 15 minutes). If a user does not respond to a session prompt within five minutes, the session will terminate, requiring re-authentication.

5. **Account Lockout Mechanism**

components.title: Paychex (API)
components.description: Payroll services.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
Authentication for the Paychex API, which provides payroll services, is implemented using several robust methods to ensure secure access to the system. The primary authentication methods include:

1. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access, enhancing security by requiring users to provide multiple forms of verification, such as a password and a second factor like a security key or an authenticator app. This is enforced through Azure AD and applies to both privileged and non-privileged accounts.

2. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users must create unique usernames and strong passwords that meet specific complexity requirements. Passwords are masked during entry to prevent unauthorized viewing. The system enforces a maximum of five consecutive invalid login attempts, after which accounts are temporarily locked for thirty minutes.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in again. This is particularly useful for government agency customers who may use hardware-based PIV or CAC cards.

4. **Session Management**: User sessions are monitored, and after fifteen minutes of inactivity, users are prompted to confirm their presence. If there is no response within five minutes, the session is terminated,

components.title: SendGrid (API)
components.description: Email services.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
The authentication methods implemented for the SendGrid (API) service, as part of the ACME system, include password-based authentication, multi-factor authentication (MFA), and single sign-on (SSO). 

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Each user is required to have a unique username and password for accessing the ACME Pro Application. Passwords must meet complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access to the ACME Pro Application and Azure resources. Users must provide a second form of verification, such as a security key or an authentication app, in addition to their password. This is enforced through Azure AD/Entra policies, which require MFA for both privileged and non-privileged accounts.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO via OIDC/OAuth 2.x, allowing users to authenticate using their organizational credentials. This integration is particularly beneficial for government agencies that may use hardware-based authentication methods like PIV or CAC cards.

4. **Session Management**: Users are automatically logged out after a period of inactivity (15 minutes), requiring re-authentication to resume

components.title: Netsuite (Billing)
components.description: Billing services.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
Netsuite (Billing) implements several robust authentication methods to ensure secure access to its billing services:

1. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access to the ACME Pro Application and Azure services. Users must provide multiple forms of verification, such as a password and a second factor like a security key (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens). This requirement enhances security by ensuring that even if a password is compromised, unauthorized access is still prevented.

2. **Password-Based Authentication**: All users, including both privileged and non-privileged accounts, must utilize unique usernames and strong passwords that meet complexity requirements. Passwords are obscured during entry to protect them from unauthorized viewing.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each. This is particularly beneficial for government agencies that may use hardware-based Personal Identity Verification (PIV) cards or Common Access Cards (CAC).

4. **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: Access permissions are assigned based on user roles, ensuring that individuals can only access the information necessary for their job functions. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized

components.title: Contentful (HTML5 Content)
components.description: Content management.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
In the Contentful service, authentication is implemented using several methods to ensure secure access to the system. The primary authentication methods include:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users are required to create a unique username and password for accessing the ACME Pro Application. Passwords must meet specific complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access and is enforced for both privileged and non-privileged accounts. Users must provide a second form of verification, which can include security keys (like FIDO 2 Tokens) or other CISA-approved methods. This adds an additional layer of security beyond just the password.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in again. This is particularly useful for government agencies that require integration with existing identity management systems.

4. **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: Access permissions are assigned based on user roles, ensuring that users have the least privilege necessary to perform their tasks. This is managed through security groups and unique user IDs.

5. **Session Management**

components.title: Maxio (API)
components.description: Financial operations.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
Maxio (API) implements a robust authentication framework to secure access to its financial operations. The primary authentication methods used include:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users are required to create unique usernames and passwords for their accounts within the ACME Pro Application. Passwords must meet complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access to the ACME Pro Application and Azure resources. Users must provide a second form of verification, such as a security key (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or an authentication app, in addition to their password. This enhances security by requiring multiple forms of identification before granting access.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate across multiple applications using a single set of credentials. This includes integration with government agencies' existing identity management systems, enabling seamless access while maintaining security.

4. **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: Access permissions are assigned based on user roles, ensuring that individuals can only access the resources necessary for their job functions. This is enforced through security groups and unique user IDs.

5.

components.title: Approved 3rd Party Platforms Azure Hosted
components.description: Approved third-party platforms hosted within Azure environment.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
The authentication methods implemented for the Approved 3rd Party Platforms hosted within the Azure environment include:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Each user is assigned a unique username and password for accessing the ACME Pro Application. Passwords must meet complexity requirements, including characters from multiple categories (uppercase, lowercase, digits, and special characters).

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access, including access to the ACME Pro Application and Azure resources. Users must provide a second form of verification, such as a security key (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or a mobile authenticator app, to enhance security against unauthorized access.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra ID, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one. This is particularly useful for government agencies that require integration with their existing identity management systems.

4. **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: Access permissions are assigned based on user roles, ensuring that users only have access to the resources necessary for their job functions. This principle of least privilege helps minimize potential security risks.

5. **Session Management**: User sessions are

The DNS Made Easy service implements several authentication methods to ensure secure access to its domain name resolution functionalities. The primary authentication methods used include:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users are required to create unique usernames and passwords for their accounts. This is enforced through Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), which manages user identities.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access to the DNS service. Users must provide a second form of verification, such as a security key or a one-time code sent to their mobile device, in addition to their password. This enhances security by requiring multiple forms of identification.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The service supports SSO through Azure AD, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in again. This is particularly useful for government agencies that require integration with their existing identity management systems.

The ACME Pro Application implements robust authentication methods to ensure secure access for users. The primary methods used are:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Each user is required to have a unique user ID and password. Strong password policies are enforced, requiring passwords to contain a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all users accessing the ACME Pro Application, particularly for privileged accounts. This involves providing a second form of verification, such as a security key (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or an authentication app, in addition to the password. MFA is also required for remote access to the Azure environment.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in again. This is particularly useful for government agencies that may require integration with their existing identity management systems.

ACME Pro implements a robust authentication system to secure access to its services, particularly for external connectivity. The primary authentication methods used are:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: All users, including privileged and non-privileged accounts, are required to have unique usernames and strong passwords that meet complexity requirements (including uppercase, lowercase, digits, and special characters). 

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all access to the ACME Pro Application, particularly for privileged accounts. Users must provide a second form of verification, which can include security keys (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or other CISA-approved methods. This adds an additional layer of security beyond just passwords.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one. This is particularly useful for government agency customers who may use PIV or CAC cards for authentication.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
The ACME Pro Application implements several robust authentication methods to ensure secure access to its services. 

1. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged and non-privileged accounts accessing the ACME Pro Application. Users must provide multiple forms of verification, such as a password and a second factor like a security key (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or an authentication app. This requirement enhances security by ensuring that access is granted only to verified users.

2. **Password-Based Authentication**: Each user is assigned a unique username and password. Strong password policies are enforced, requiring passwords to contain characters from multiple categories (uppercase, lowercase, digits, and special characters). This is to prevent unauthorized access through weak passwords.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The application supports SSO, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple services without needing to log in again. This is particularly useful for government agencies that require integration with their existing identity providers.

The ACME Pro Application implements several authentication methods to ensure secure access to its services. The primary methods include:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Each user is required to have a unique user ID and password. Passwords must adhere to strong complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all users, especially for privileged access. Users must provide a second form of verification, such as a security key (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or a mobile authenticator app, in addition to their password. This adds an extra layer of security against unauthorized access.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: The system supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one. This is particularly useful for government agencies that require integration with their existing identity management systems.

4. **Session Management**: User sessions are monitored and require re-authentication after periods of inactivity (e.g., 15 minutes). If a user does not respond to a prompt within five minutes, the session is terminated, requiring a new login.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
ACME Pro implements a robust authentication framework to ensure secure access to its Content Delivery Network (CDN) and associated web applications. The primary authentication methods used are:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: Users are required to create unique usernames and passwords to access the ACME Pro Application. Passwords must meet complexity requirements, including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters.

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access, enhancing security by requiring users to provide additional verification factors beyond just their password. This includes the use of FIPS 140-2/3 validated security keys or other CISA-approved methods. MFA is also enforced for remote access to the ACME Pro Application and Azure infrastructure.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: ACME supports SSO through Azure Entra, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications without needing to log in separately for each one. This is particularly beneficial for government agency customers who may use hardware-based PIV or CAC cards.

4. **Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)**: Access permissions are assigned based on user roles, ensuring that individuals only have access to the information necessary for their job functions

components.title: DNSMadeEasy, Azure DNS Service (DNS)
components.description: Resolves domain names for the ACME Pro services within the Azure environment.DNS queries from ACME Pro services and external users to resolve domain names.

props.name: authentication-method
props.remarks:
ACME Pro implements a robust authentication system to secure access to its services, particularly within the Azure environment. The primary authentication methods used are:

1. **Password-Based Authentication**: All users, including administrators, must have unique usernames and strong passwords that adhere to specific complexity requirements (including a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, digits, and special characters).

2. **Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)**: MFA is mandatory for all privileged access to the ACME Pro Application and Azure resources. This includes the use of FIPS 140-3 validated security keys (e.g., FIDO 2 Tokens) or other MFA methods approved by CISA. Users must provide multiple forms of verification to authenticate, enhancing security against unauthorized access.

3. **Single Sign-On (SSO)**: ACME supports SSO through Azure Entra and can integrate with customer identity providers using OIDC/OAuth 2.x. This allows users to access multiple applications with a single set of credentials, streamlining the authentication process while maintaining security.

4. **Session Management**: Users are required to re-authenticate after periods of inactivity (15 minutes) or if they have been logged in for an extended duration (more than 12 hours). Additionally, sessions are

capabilities.name: Domain
capabilities.description: This capability supports key system functionality.

incorporates-components.description: Manages domain name resolution for the CSO.

capabilities.name: NetworkEndpoint
capabilities.description: This capability supports key system functionality.

incorporates-components.description: Manages and secures external connections to the ACME System, ensuring encrypted data transmission.
Distributes internal traffic securely among backend web application services. Traffic between the external boundary (WAF) and the backend web application services.
Facilitates secure external connections to internal services by mapping public to private IP addresses. External connectivity for traffic entering the ACME Pro environment.

capabilities.name: Firewall
capabilities.description: This capability supports key system functionality.

incorporates-components.description: Secures web application traffic by filtering and monitoring HTTP requests between users and web apps. External internet boundary, protecting traffic between users and internal load balancers.

capabilities.name: Workflow
capabilities.description: This capability supports key system functionality.

incorporates-components.description: Manages workflow orchestration and processing for the ACME System.
Orchestrates workflows and manages business process execution. Workflow Processor Resource Group for executing business logic within ACME Pro.
